CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 13, 1953, pg. 12, reads: "Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Skinner III - Harris Photo". Portions of accompanying article read: "Central Baptist Church was the setting for Delores Beatrice Mack's marriage to Samuel Skinner III on Saturday, June 6.  Chantilly lace and nylon tulle over a stain full skirt which ended in a sweeping train, fashioned the gown worn by the bride.  It was designed and made by the bride, who attends Clarissa's School of Fashion.  She wore a fingertip veil and carried a white Bible with a white orchid.  The candlelight, double-ring service was performed by the Rev. Cornell E. Talley.  Maid of honor was Leonora Jane Smalley, who wore a floor length gown of scalloped lace and tulle over a full taffeta skirt.  The other attendant were Delores Taylor, Shirley Skinner, Ho-Ann Freeman, Lois Garner and Viney Jones.  They wore matching gowns of lime green and similar headdress and carried yellow colonial bouquets. Brenda and Belinda Blake were the flower girls and wore floor-length gowns of tulle over white taffeta.  Male Attendants - Best man was James Stucky. Ushers were John Johnson, William Horne, Joseph Johnson, Samuel Moses and Bubbie Hairston.  Curtis Davis was the ring-bearer.  Marie Miller was the organist and Eleanor Morrison was soloist.  The pretty ceremony was directed by Mrs. Mary White.  The bride is the daughter of Ms. and Mrs. George Mack and the groom is the sone of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Skinner II....Junior aides were Ophelia Brown and Martin Jennings. Senior aides were Mrs. Lula Woodson, Mrs. Freddie Johnson, Mrs. Nola Gloster, Mrs. Mildred Green, Mrs. Mattie Marlin, Mrs. Lillie Mill, Mrs. Thelma Snowden, Mrs. Willie Williams and Mrs. Elizabeth Palmer..."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of women and men gathered around groom Samuel Skinner III wearing light colored dinner jacket and dark bow tie, bride Delores Beatrice Mack Skinner wearing satin and lace gown with scalloped v-neck, and ring bearer Curtis Davis, posed in Central Baptist Church
